update.description:
This PR replaces the socket implementation (server/socket.js) with the one in cloudsim-grant.
While the code is mostly the same (socket.js was "moved" to cloudsim-grant), the notifications are not the same. Thus, upstream projects (cloudsim-widgets) will have to upgrade.

* replace sockets with resource updates

* removed unused files

* comment edit

* added tests
update.title: Socket refactor

content.raw: That PR has been merge (thanks) and so this one now has the performance enhancement.
content.html: That PR has been merge (thanks) and so this one now has the performance enhancement.

content.html: sounds good

content.raw: In this implementation, he socket doesn't carry the state of the resource, simply that it has been updated. The cloudsim-widgets gets the state via REST whenever a socket message is received.
content.html: In this implementation, he socket doesn't carry the state of the resource, simply that it has been updated. The cloudsim-widgets gets the state via REST whenever a socket message is received.

content.raw:
I'm not sure the status update is helpful here. LAUNCHING is the only state that was tested previously, and the socket connection is there to notify of changes, not a heartbeat (that functionality can be done by polling from the client).

Also, this could be a challenge as it looks like in the test setup, some sockets events are ignored (like the create event when it is followed by an update).
content.html:
I'm not sure the status update is helpful here. LAUNCHING is the only state that was tested previously, and the socket connection is there to notify of changes, not a heartbeat (that functionality can be done by polling from the client).

Also, this could be a challenge as it looks like in the test setup, some sockets events are ignored (like the create event when it is followed by an update).

content.raw: Possibly not related to this PR, but is `server/events/model.js` being used? It's the only place where redis is used directly, we could get rid of this dependency.

content.html: I don't think its necessary to verify each field in every tests. This test is about the socket functionality.

content.raw: I saw the update operation being tested for creating and deleting simulators, but never when the simulator is actually updated. This is necessary for when the machine changes status from LAUNCHING to RUNNING, for example. Is there a way to test that this is working now that we don't have periodic status updates?
content.html: I saw the update operation being tested for creating and deleting simulators, but never when the simulator is actually updated. This is necessary for when the machine changes status from LAUNCHING to RUNNING, for example. Is there a way to test that this is working now that we don't have periodic status updates?

content.raw: There are no more tests for clients without permissions, right? Not sure how to do it now that we don't have periodic updates anymore. Maybe when terminating a simulator, we can have create a client which doesn't have permission and check that it never gets the terminating update?

content.raw: You mentioned that we can't be sure about the order in which the socket and the REST response are received, right? Do you think we should use a counter trick here to make sure both are called? Is there a chance that the `done()` above is called and this block is never checked?
content.html: You mentioned that we can't be sure about the order in which the socket and the REST response are received, right? Do you think we should use a counter trick here to make sure both are called? Is there a chance that the done() above is called and this block is never checked?
